Toughening of Epoxy Nanocomposites: Nano and Hybrid Effects
BAHEREH T. MAROUF1,2, YIU-WING MAI1, REZA BAGHERI3, AND RAYMOND A. PEARSON4
1Centre for Advanced Materials Technology (CAMT), School of Aerospace,
Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering J07, The University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia 2Materials Science and Engineering Group, Faculty of Engineering, Urmia
University, Urmia, Iran 3Polymeric Material Research Group, Department of Materials Science and
Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran 4Center for Polymer Science and Engineering, Department of Materials Science
and Engineering, Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA, USA
In this paper, we review recent progress made in the field of epoxy-based binary and ternary nanocomposites containing three-, two-, and one-dimensional (i.e., 3D-, 2D-, and 1D) nano-size fillers with a special focus on their fracture behaviors. Despite investigations conducted so far to evaluate the crack-resistance of epoxy nanocomposites and attempts made to clarify the controlling toughening mechanisms of these materials, some questions remain unsolved. It is shown that silica nanoparticles can be as effective as rubber particles in improving the fracture toughness/energy; but incorporation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) or clay platelets in epoxy matrices delays crack growth only modestly. The “nano” effects of silica (<25 vol.%) and rubber (>10 wt.%) nanoparticles in toughening epoxy resin are confirmed by comparison with silica and rubber micro-particles of the same loading. There is clear evidence of both synergistic and additive toughening effects in the silica/rubber/ epoxy ternary nanocomposites. In addition, positive hybrid toughening effect has been observed in the nano-rubber/CNT/epoxy composites; however, a negative hybrid effect is predominant in nano-clay/nano-rubber/epoxy ternary nano-composites. Future research directions for epoxy-based nanocomposites towards multi-functional applications are discussed.
Keywords fracture, toughening mechanisms, binary/ternary nanocomposite, epoxy, interface

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the mid-90s, with growing interests in nanotechnology, incorporation of nanofillers into
polymers has attracted great attention of both academic and engineering communities. Thus

far, many studies have been conducted on the mechanical performance of nanocomposites,
both experimentally and theoretically. Extensive investigations have been performed on determining the Young’s modulus,1–10 strength,2,4,7–9,11 fracture toughness,5,12–17 and deformation behavior17–22 of polymer nanocomposites. More recent work has focused specifically on the surface properties of such materials by using more sophisticated nanoindentation devices.23–26 Other studies have adopted available theoretical models to study the effects of stiffening27–33 and strengthening11,34 due to nanofillers in polymers, and their influences on the mechanical properties of the interface region.29,35–39
Based on their shapes, nanofillers are classified into three categories including particles
having three dimensions in nano scale as opposed to fibers/tubes and platelets having two- and one-dimension in nano-scale, respectively35 (Fig. 1). By this definition, silica and rubber nanoparticles are identified as three-dimensional (3D) nanofillers; carbon nanotubes and halloysite
nanotubes are considered as two-dimensional (2D), while clay and graphene nanoplatelets are
examples of one-dimensional (1D) nanofillers. The importance of the shape of a nanofiller is
due to its influence on the overall interface area between filler and matrix. However, the size of
the interface in a two-phasematerial dictates the volume fraction of the interphase regionwhere
the polymer matrix properties differ from those of the bulk polymer. It is well-documented that
in polymer matrix composites, there is a thin interphase layer around the particles in which the polymer chains have different conformation to their counterparts in the bulk.40,41 The size of this interphase region in themicro-composites is rather small and does not change themechani-
cal properties very much. In polymer nanocomposites, however, the volume fraction of this
region can be quite significant and hence may affect considerably their mechanical properties.
To conclude, the interfacial volume fraction depends on the shape and size and loading of the
nano-filler (see Fig. 2). Thus, smaller fillers with three-dimensions in nano-scale have a larger
interfacial volume fraction than that of the 2D nanofillers at the same loading, indicating 3D nanofillers could be more effective than 2D nanofillers.35 In their review paper, Schadler et al.35 have shown the positive effects of the interfacial area on themechanical, thermo-mechanical, and tribological properties of polymer nanocomposites.
In the past few years, there have been several reviews on thermoplastic and thermoset
polymer nanocomposites addressing broadly the different aspects in preparation, process-
ing, properties (physical, mechanical, thermo-mechanical, functional, etc.), and applications.42–47 Even though fracture toughness is an important property in engineering
applications, so far, there is only one review dedicated to the energy absorption capability of polymer nanocomposites.48 To redress this issue, the current review focuses on the
fracture behaviors of epoxy composites containing 3D, 2D, and 1D nanofillers owing to

the high demand of epoxies in a variety of industries (energy, transportation, electronics,
construction, and adhesives among others).
This review critically examines the “nano effect” and “hybrid effect” on toughening
of binary and ternary epoxy nanocomposites, respectively. The binary composites studied
include soft and rigid nanofillers in epoxy matrix. In ternary composites, soft rubber par-
ticles, either nano or micron size, and rigid nanofillers are incorporated simultaneously
into epoxy matrix. Addition of rubber particles (or modifiers) in epoxies is an established industry practice to overcome the inherent brittleness of these materials. In the past ten years, nanostructured rubbers have been used to toughen epoxies49–60 with good effect
and these are also reviewed herein.
Following the above brief introduction, Section 2 presents an overview of the crack-
resistance and toughening mechanisms of 3D particulate/epoxy binary and ternary nano-
composites. Section 3 is concerned with the fracture toughness behaviors of 2D nano-
tube/epoxy nanocomposites; and Section 4 deals with the fracture characteristics of 1D
nanoplatelet/epoxy binary and ternary nanocomposites. Section 5 compares the toughening efficiency of epoxy composites containing 3D, 2D, and 1D nano-fillers and addresses
their potential applications in different industry. Finally, Section 6 summarizes the advan-
ces made on epoxy nanocomposites, where we are now, and points to future research
directions in this field.

sections.heading: 2.1 Binary Nanocomposites with Silica Particles
sections.text:
Micro-sized silica particles are well-known fillers for improving the mechanical properties, especially fracture toughness* of epoxies.61–69 Recently, the addition of nano-sized
Figure 2. Variation of volume fraction of interfacial polymer versus volume fraction of nanofiller. The effects of particle shape and size on the fraction of interfacial region are also shown. Data from Schadler et al.35

silica particles has been studied by many researchers and the positive effects of silica
nano-particles on the mechanical properties of epoxy resins such as elastic modulus, hardness, impact resistance, and fracture toughness have been demonstrated.10,61,70-80 Fu et al.81 provided a review on the effects of particle size, interfacial strength, and filler load-
ing on the elastic modulus, strength, fracture toughness, and impact behaviors of polymer
composites containing nano/micro-size particulates.
Table 1 summarizes published reports on silica nanoparticle-filled epoxies and evaluates the influence of these nanofillers on increasing fracture toughness. From this table, the beneficial effect of silica nanoparticles on the plane strain fracture toughness (KIC) of low, moderate, and high Tg epoxies is obvious. Typically, 35-145% increase in fracture toughness has been obtained when silica nanoparticles were incorporated into epoxy resins.
Figure 3 compares the toughening efficiency of nano- and micro-silica particles in
terms of the normalized fracture toughness (KIC/KIC,m), Fig. 3a, and normalized fracture energy (GIC/GIC,m), Fig. 3b. KIC and KIC,m are, respectively, the fracture toughness values of nano-/micro- composites and neat epoxy. Similarly, GIC and GIC,m are the corresponding fracture energy values. Subscripts “m” stand for epoxy matrix. Some general
comments can be made. First, the incorporation of silica particles, either nano-size or
micro-size, into neat epoxies increases KIC and GIC. Second, nano-size fillers are more effective tougheners than micro-size fillers over the full range of filler loading up to
60 wt.% (i.e., 25 vol.%). This shows that the improvement in crack-growth resistance can
be achieved at a lower loading of silica nanoparticles compared to silica micro-particles.
Hence, this confirms the presence of a “nano-effect” of silica nanoparticles over silica
micro-particles as a toughening agent for epoxy resins. Figure 3 also shows that KIC/KIC, m and GIC/GIC,m of silica/epoxy nanocomposites increase monotonically with nano-filler content. Uniform dispersion of fillers in the matrix is a key parameter to achieve high val-
ues of fracture toughness specifically when the volume fraction is high. Otherwise, reduction of fracture toughness at high filler loading due to the formation of agglomerates can
occur. Hence, to obtain uniform dispersion of silica nanoparticles and sustain a narrow
particle size distribution, researchers have used organosilane-treated silica nanoparticles in the form of a colloidal sol in epoxy matrix, which are commercially available.70,72
Spherical silica nanoparticles in the range of 5-2000 nm are synthesized through a tech-
nique consisting of hydrolysis and polycondensation of a metal alkoxides (Si(OR)4) such as tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS)[Si(OC2H5)4]. Further information can be found in articles published by Green et al.82 and Rahman et al.83
The important effect of particle size on the crack growth behavior of polymers containing micro-sized particles has been well documented.63,66,78,81,84-90 It is shown that
both the KIC and GIC values increase when the silica particle size is increased from 2 to 47 mm.66,81 However, in the range 0.2 to 1.56 mm, the silica particles cause a negative effect on KIC. 61 Whether a particle size effect in the nanometer range exists in polymer nanocomposites has been the subject of several studies.70,91 Figure 4 examines the effect
of particle size on epoxies reinforced with nano-sized fillers. Comparisons of nanocompo-
sites containing 23, 74, and 170 nm silica particles show little or no particle size effect when the same surface treatment (organosilane treatment) is applied for all three particle sizes.70,91 This agrees with the results reported by Liang and Pearson72 when a diglycidyl
ether bisphenol A (DGEBA) epoxy was incorporated with 20 and 80 nm silica particles.
However, a positive effect on fracture toughness of silica/epoxy composites containing bimodal particle size distribution was observed by Dittanet and Pearson92 when the total filler loading was maintained at 10 vol.%. The outcomes gave a »30% increase in

fracture toughness of neat epoxy having a combination of 7.5 vol.% silica nanoparticles
and 2.5 vol.% micro-particles when compared to either monotonic nano-sized silica/
epoxy or micro-sized silica/epoxy systems. It is noteworthy that the size variation of nanoparticles does not affect the fracture toughness in this study.92
Properties of the interface cannot be neglected in nanocomposites since the surface
area increases substantially in nano-scale and this affects significantly the fracture behav-
iors of these composites. For micro-composites, the importance of interfacial strength between filler and epoxy matrix is well-known.93,94 Kawaguchi and Pearson93 studied the
effect of interface strength on the fracture toughness of micro-sized glass/epoxy compo-
sites (Fig. 4). Their KIC results revealed that higher toughening efficiency is endowed by a weak interface between micro-particles and matrix rather than by a strong interface when the same size particles (42 mm) are uniformly dispersed in epoxy. The weak inter-
face facilitates the particle/matrix debonding concomitant by remarkable matrix plasticity in which the fracture toughness increases to 2.5 MPa.m0.5 at only 25 wt.% (i.e., 10 vol.%)
Figure 3. Variation of (a) normalized fracture toughness, and (b) normalized fracture energy of silica-filled epoxies versus silica micro-/nanoparticle content. The effect of particle size in nano-scale is also shown. KIC, GIC, and E values are obtained from published data of silica micro-/nano-particle filled epoxies, from Refs.61,66,70,71,73,75,78 with permission. In some cases, GIC values are calculated using GIC D K2IC/E. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

micro-filler loading.93 However, for the strong interface, the same toughness value can
only be obtained when 70 wt.% (i.e., 30 vol.%) micron-sized glass particles are intro-
duced into the matrix. It is also observed that there is an initial increase followed by a
gradual decrease in fracture toughness as a function of glass particle loading for the
micro-composites with a weak interface; however, the fracture toughness increases continuously with increasing glass particle loading for those composites with a strong inter-
face. This difference in the toughness behavior is associated with different toughening
mechanisms activated in each case. For the micro-composites with a weak interface, the
main energy dissipation mechanism is shear deformation of the epoxy matrix following
particle debonding. With this scenario, it is envisaged that there is an optimal filler con-
tent at which the fracture toughness is maximum; but beyond that, there is much less
matrix material to undergo plastic shear deformation and absorb energy. Figure 4 suggests that the optimal filler loading is »25 wt.% (or 10 vol.%).93 By contrast, in the case of a strong interface, the predominant toughening mechanism is crack-pinning and the
toughness increases continuously to 70 wt.% (or 30 vol.%) of micro-fillers. This observa-
tion is consistent with the crack pinning model which predicts a continuous increase of
toughness with filler loading.
Despite the known effect of interface strength in epoxy filled with micro-sized par-
ticles, such an effect has not been investigated in silica nanoparticle reinforced epoxies.72,93 The role of interface strength, however, has been the subject of investigations on epoxies reinforced with alumina95 and aluminum96 nanoparticles. These studies reported no substantial effect of interface strength on fracture toughness. Any effort on
surface modification to improve the interface strength may affect the nanoparticle disper-
sion, which, in turn, will influence the fracture toughness, not just the interface strength
itself. Further work is needed to differentiate these two factors.
Another important factor on nano-toughening is the effect of matrix properties. Liang and Pearson72 studied the effect of matrix ductility on KIC and GIC of a DGEBA-amine cured epoxy with 25 wt.% (i.e., 17.5 vol.%) 20 nm silica particles. The matrix ductility
Figure 4. Variation of fracture toughness with filler loading due to strong and weak interfacial strength between glass micro-particles and a DGEBA-based epoxy cured with piperidine (PIP). Data for silica nanoparticles of three different sizes are also given. The KIC values are obtained from Dittanet and Pearson70 and Kawaguchi and Pearson91 with permission. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

was altered by changing the molecular weight of epoxy as a function of cure temperature.72 The results obtained exhibited the beneficial effect of increasing epoxy molecular weight on toughening due to the silica nanoparticles.72 Also, more toughness improvement is obtained when the epoxy crosslink density is reduced.97–100 Similar effects have
been found in rubber-modified epoxies containing either nano-sized or micro-sized particles.101,102 Other studies have also reported better efficiency of silica nanoparticles on
toughening of epoxies with a less brittle epoxy, for example, diglycidyl ether bisphenol
A/tetraethylene pentamine (DGEBA/TEPA), compared to a more brittle epoxy like DGEBA/diamino diphenyl sulfone (DDS).73 Therefore, silica nanoparticles are more effi-
cient in improving the fracture toughness of more ductile epoxies which can undergo and
is capable of more plastic deformation. Further details are given in Sub-section 2.1.1.
The importance of inter-particle distance on the toughening effect of nano-silica has
been raised by several investigators who have argued that the fracture toughness of silica/
epoxy nano-composites increases rapidly as the edge-to-edge ligament distance between the nanoparticles decreases. Zhang et al.78 hypothesized that at a high enough filler load-
ing, a 3D network of interfacial polymer forms around the particles which differs from the bulk of the matrix and which controls the mechanical performance of the composite.78
2.1.1 Toughening Mechanisms. Table 1 shows the toughening mechanisms proposed for silica/epoxy nanocomposites. Johnsen et al.75 studied the possibility of different
toughening mechanisms which may work in these silica/epoxy nanocomposites. The pos-
sibility of formation of an immobilized polymer layer around the silica nanoparticles as
the effective toughening mechanism was refuted by these researchers since there was no
significant increase in the glass transition temperature (Tg) of the nanocomposites compared to the neat epoxy. They also claimed that, since nanoparticles are much smaller
than the crack opening displacement at the crack instability point, crack pinning, and
crack deflection cannot be very effective toughening mechanisms in these nanocomposites.75 Specifically, for crack deflection, no correlations were found between average surface roughness and toughness increment with increasing nanoparticle loading.75 Similar
conclusions have been made by other investigators on the toughening of epoxy-based nanocomposites containing either 13 nm alumina or 300 nm titania particles.103 That is,
contributions of crack deflection and crack pinning on the improvement of fracture toughness,103 fracture energy,103 and fatigue crack propagation (FCP) resistance95,103 in these
particulate/epoxy nanocomposites are limited.
Based on scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) images, Johnsen et al.75 first proposed debonding of silica nanoparticles and subsequent
plastic matrix void growth as the dominant toughening mechanisms in an anhydride cured
silica/epoxy nanocomposite. These observations were also reported in a more recent study on an amine cured nanosilica/epoxy by Liu et al.71 Later, Pearson and colleagues70,72 evi-
denced silica nanoparticles debonding, shear yielding, and plastic void growth (but no
crack pinning) around the crack tip in a toughenable, low Tg, lightly cross-linked epoxy. This agrees with the observations by Hsieh et al.104 and the very recent work by Bray et al.91 Figure 5 shows transmission optical micrographs (TOM) taken near the crack tip region from the mid-section of the nanocomposite containing 25 wt.% (17.5 vol.%) of
80 nm silica particles under both bright field and cross-polarized light. Massive shear
bands and matrix dilation can be seen. The microscopy studies also indicate scaling of
the crack tip plastic zone size with silica nanoparticle loading corresponding to the obtained fracture toughness values.72 Furthermore, the sizes of measured plastic zones72 agree well with those values calculated from the Irwin model similar to Hsieh et al.104 All

these results indicate that matrix plastic shear deformation is the single major toughening
mechanism in silica nanoparticle/epoxy composites.
In Section 2.1, it is suggested that a more ductile epoxy can gain more in toughness
from incorporation of silica nanoparticles compared to a less ductile epoxy. As explained above, since the major work dissipation is matrix shear yielding and plastic void growth,
it is essential that the silica/epoxy nanocomposites have large capacities to accommodate
such plastic deformation. Hence, if the epoxy matrix is too brittle, it cannot deform suffi-
ciently during fracture and the toughness is low. However, if the matrix is highly plasti-
cally deformable, it can benefit from the presence of silica nanoparticles which can
debond and activate the aforementioned toughening mechanisms of plastic void growth
and matrix shear banding. That is, when the epoxy matrix is less brittle but more ductile,
we can obtain high fracture toughness in these nanocomposites. It should be noted that the epoxy matrix only have to be sufficiently ductile to undergo the crack-tip plastic
deformation processes during fracture.
2.1.2 Nanomechanics Modeling of Toughening. To provide an in-depth understanding
of the nanomechanics of toughening mechanisms in silica/epoxy nanocomposites, efforts
have been made to correlate the obtained fracture energy results to micromechanical models.70,72,75,91,104 Hence, the model originally suggested by Huang and Kinloch105 for
rubber-modified composites, has been used to predict GC in silica/epoxy nano -composites. The toughness equations given by Huang and Kinloch105 are:

Here, GC,m is the fracture energy of neat epoxy and c the overall toughening contribution; DGs and DGV are contributions from localized shear bands and plastic void growth, respectively. mm is the material pressure coefficient; ѵfp and ѵfv are volume fraction of reinforcing particles and voids, respectively. syc is plane-strain compressive true yield stress and gf shear fracture strain of neat epoxy; rp, ry, and ry,m are radius of reinforcing particle, plane-strain crack-tip plastic zone of modified epoxy, and plastic zone in neat
epoxy, respectively; KP is the maximum stress concentration factor of von Mises stress around a reinforcing particle, and syt tensile yield stress of neat epoxy. KC,m is fracture toughness of neat epoxy. Further details are given by Bray et al.91
Considering the above, the analytical models used by Johnsen et al.75 as well as Liang and Pearson72 over-estimated the plastic work for void growth due to the assump-
tion that all particles debond from the matrix prior to crack growth. To overcome this problem, void growth contribution based on the actual fraction of debonded nanoparticles ( 15%) was used and which was supported by both microscopy studies70,91,104 and finite element modeling predictions.91 In recent studies70,104 matrix shear yielding was evi-
denced (in Fig. 5) and this is added as an extra toughening mechanism using the model proposed by Huang and Kinloch.105 Considering these two facts, good agreement
between measured and predicted fracture energies is obtained (see Fig. 6). From the model predictions with Eq. (1) and Fig. 6, it can be seen that matrix shear yielding (DGs) makes a larger contribution than void growth (0.143DGv) to the total fracture energy GC in silica/epoxy nanocomposites containing less than 20 wt.% nano-silica; but this trend is
reversed with void growth contribution more dominant than shear yielding for higher
nano-silica loading. Hence, the ratio between the contributions of these two mechanisms
drops with increasing silica nanoparticles loading. For example, the contribution of shear yielding to the fracture energy enhancement is reduced from »70% to 47% and that of void growth is increased from »30% to 53% if silica loading is increased from 5 to 25 wt.% (2.5 to 13 vol.%). In the above calculations, it is assumed that shear bands initiate from all nanoparticles according to Dekkers and Heikens106 but only 14.3% nanoparticles are debonded91 followed by plastic void growth. This ratio depends on the number
of particles which initiate shear yielding and those particles which promote matrix
dilation.
To conclude, silica nanoparticles are an effective toughening agent for ductile
epoxies which can plastically deform and the “nano” toughening effect is confirmed in
silica/epoxy nano -composites. Crack growth originates from the debonding of silica

sections.heading: 2.2 Binary Nanocomposites with Rubber Particles
sections.text:
Rubber particles are well-known toughening agents for polymers, especially epoxy resins.107-111 Rubber modifiers are used in the forms of reactive oligomers (e.g., carboxyl
terminated butadiene acrylonitrile CTBN, amine terminated butadiene acrylonitrile ATBN, etc.),17,107,108 preformed particles,17,112,113 block copolymers,53,54,57,59,114-117 and block ionomer complexes.50,52 Bagheri et al.109 comprehensively reviewed the literature
of rubber-toughened epoxies using either nano- or micro-size particles. They focused on
the influences of effective parameters such as matrix ductility, modifier content, morphol-
ogy, cavitation resistance, and interface on the fracture toughness of epoxy resins. Below, we examine the crack resistance of nano-sized rubber-modified epoxies to ascertain if a
“nano-effect” on toughness exists in these nanocomposites.
Figure 7 compares the toughening efficiency of nano-size (solid symbols) and micro-
size (unfilled symbols) rubber particles in epoxy polymers in normalized K- and G-plots.
As shown in Fig. 7a, the rubber nanoparticles in the form of spherical and wormlike micelles increase KIC monotonically with rubber loading to »25 wt.%. The micro-size rubber particles (CTBN and ATBN) may impart higher, similar or lower KIC values in epoxies at and below 10 wt.% than rubber nanoparticles. (See Fig. 7b). This depends on the nature of epoxy and the rubber modifier, concentration of rubbery phase, and interface
properties. Above 10 wt.% loading, micro-rubber particles cannot increase KIC further as it either remains constant or drops. Hence, a “nano” effect on KIC owing to the nano-size rubber particles is clearly displayed beyond 10 wt.%. Since many rubber modifiers are
used, such as core-shell particles or block copolymers, consist of both rubbery and glassy
phases, it is important to realize that the real rubber content is less than the nominal

DGs and DGv are contributions from localized matrix shear banding and matrix plastic void growth, respectively. Data obtained from Bray et al.91

ening has not been investigated. The glassy phase controls dispersion in core-shell rubber
particles and rubber particles from self-assembling block copolymers. In BCPs, the ratio
of the glassy block to the rubber block can determine whether spherical micelles, vesicles,
or worm-like micelles are formed. It is also believed that the glassy phase may contribute
to the stability of void growth of the matrix polymer though this remains to be proven.
A recent analysis by Williams118 indicated the existence of “nano-toughening” effect in polymers containing particles less than 50 nm. The analysis predicts more significant toughening effect for very small (»10 nm) particles. It is shown that good particle dispersion and high matrix ductility are crucial factors to obtain high fracture toughness in
nanoparticle/polymer composites but are not so important for micro-particle/polymer composites.118 Interestingly, it is suggested that cavitation occurs in micron rubber particles (2 mm) but debonding happens with nano-size rubber particles (50 nm). Indepen-
dent of cavitation and debonding, the major toughening from Williams’ model is plastic

In the micron-scale, morphology is an important factor on rubber-toughening of epoxies.109,119,120 Bagheri et al.109 reviewed the sensitivity of fracture toughness to the
morphology of micro-size rubber modifiers. They showed that rubber-modified epoxies
with a co-continuous morphology yields higher fracture toughness compared to similar blends containing a uniform isolated morphology.109,119 Similarly, in the nano-scale, it is
demonstrated that nanostructured epoxies with wormlike micelles are tougher than those epoxies with spherical micelles.53,114 This is shown in Table 2 which highlights the
importance of morphology (see Fig. 8) on nano-rubber toughened epoxies. It may be
added that even for the same morphology (wormlike or spherical micelles), the toughening efficiency depends on the particle size and nano- is not always better than micron
(Fig. 7b, solid diamond versus solid square symbols) or sub-micron rubber.

2.2.1 Toughening Mechanisms. The toughening mechanisms of rubber nanoparticle/ epoxy composites have been studied using microscopy techniques,17,51,53,55,58,114,121,122
revealing nano-cavitation of rubber particles concomitant with matrix plastic deformation (i.e., shear yielding and plastic void growth) as the effective means of energy dissipation.17,51,53,55,114,121,122 Quantitative toughness estimates of nano-rubber (100 nm)/epoxy
based on the toughening mechanisms of matrix shear yielding and plastic void growth agree well with experimental data.123 Note that the observation of cavitation clearly contradicts the theoretical analysis of Williams118 that only debonding occurs in nano-size
rubber particles. For block copolymer and ionomer nanostructured epoxies, cavitation
and debonding of rubber particles, crack tip blunting, limited shear yielding, and bridging
of wormlike particles at the crack-wake were found in a high Tg epoxy filled with 5 wt.% wormlike rubber micelles.114 These mechanisms cannot be included in Williams’ model118 and there has been no theoretical modeling to-date of the total toughness of
these rubber modified nanostructured epoxies.

sections.heading: 2.3 Ternary Nanocomposites with Silica/Rubber Hybrids
sections.text:
Few research groups have studied the fracture behaviors of silica/rubber/epoxy ternary nano-composites.71,75,86,104,124-127 The results obtained show higher fracture toughness
(KIC) and critical energy release rate (GIC) for hybrid systems compared to silica nanoparticle/epoxies, rubber/epoxies and neat epoxies.71,75,104,125,126 Figure 9 plots the normal-
ized GIC against silica nano-particle loading for the ternary silica/rubber/epoxy and binary silica/epoxy nanocomposites. The two types of rubber particles are: (a) micron-
sized CTBN and (b) nanometer-sized core-shell rubber (CSR). Clearly, incorporation of
silica nanoparticles into either CTBN/epoxy (micro-rubber/epoxy) or CSR/epoxy (nano-
rubber/ epoxy) increases GIC of the ternary composites.
Figure 9. Variation of normalized fracture energy versus silica nanoparticle content in silica/epoxy binary nanocomposites and silica/rubber/epoxy ternary nanocomposites. GIC values of the binary and ternary nanocomposites are normalized with the fracture energy of neat epoxy (GIC,m) and are obtained from Refs.71,72,125,127 with permission. In some cases, the GIC values are calculated from: GIC D K2IC/E. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

Before discussing these results further, we need to define “hybrid” effect on toughness.71 In general, a synergistic toughness effect is defined as a hybrid improvement
which cannot be achieved by either particle working alone. One way to examine the hybrid effect on KIC and GIC is to consider for a given total particle loading in the ternary nanocomposites whether KIC and GIC follows or departs positively (or negatively) from the rule of mixtures calculated from two single-particle composites. An alternative way is
to consider how KIC and GIC change when a constant amount of one particle is added to the composites containing different amount of another particle. The hybrid effect can be
positive, negative or additive if the two toughness curves are diverging, converging or
parallel to each other. Figure 9 shows the fracture behaviors of both nano-silica binary
and ternary nanocomposites in a normalized G-plot. In the nano-silica (20 nm)/nano-rubber (100 nm) hybrids, Liu et al.71 showed no hybrid effect and the additive rule applied (see and ). In the nano-silica (20 nm)/micron-rubber (0.54 mm) hybrids, Hsieh et al.104 obtained a positive hybrid or synergistic effect (see & and █) on GIC. Similarly, Liang and Pearson125 also displayed a positive hybrid effect in their ternary composites with less than 5 wt.% silica nanoparticles (20 nm) incorporated into the CTBN (2-3 mm)/ epoxies (see D and ~). With more than 5 wt.% nano-silica particles in epoxy, a negative hybrid effect on GIC is obtained due to the agglomeration of nano-silica (see Fig. 9).
2.3.1 Toughening Mechanisms. Cavitation of rubber particles and debonding of some
silica nanoparticles in combination with matrix deformation have been observed in
epoxy-based hybrid nanocomposites containing silica nano-particles and rubber micro/ nano-particles.71,104,123,125,126 To explain the synergistic effect on GIC for nano-silica/ CTBN/epoxy composites, it has been noted that the inter-particle distance due to CTBN
(10 wt.%) is large to trigger more intensive and extensive shear yielding and matrix dila-
tion around the silica nanoparticles and increased shear band density between rubber particles.125 These interactive processes further increase the fracture toughness evidenced by the much expanded crack-tip plastic zones in the nano-silica/CTBN/epoxy ternary com-
posites in agreement with the Irwin model. For nano-silica/nano-rubber/epoxy composites 71,123 which display an additive effect on GIC, the inter-particle distance is »67 nm (10 wt.% nano-rubber) and is 2-3 times the silica nanoparticle size thereby sufficient to
allow the full toughening processes of nano-silica/epoxy to take place in cooperation with
those of nano-rubber/epoxy composites. The crack tip plastic zones of these ternary nano-
composites are only 10–15% larger than the sum of those plastic zones of the binary
nanocomposites (minus that of neat epoxy). Thus, we surmise that interactions between particles did not occur in these nano/nano ternary composites, which is different to the
nano/micro ternary composites. To understand this issue of “hybrid” effect on toughening
of ternary nanocomposites, whether the epoxy matrix is filled with nano/nano or nano/
micro particles, numerical modeling consistent with test results and observations is
needed. So far, this is lacking.

sections.heading: 3.1 Binary Nanocomposites with Carbon Nanotubes
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are generally considered as one of the potential fillers to improve the mechanical properties of polymer matrices.128-138 Questions concerning
appropriate type of CNTs, that is, single-walled CNT (SWCNT), double-walled CNT
(DWCNT), or multi-walled CNT (MWCNT), and the effectiveness of CNT surface

functionalization, dispersion and alignment139-145 are critical. Results show that the addi-
tion of all kinds of CNTs increases the tensile properties, hardness, impact resistance, and fracture toughness of epoxy resins.130,138-144,146-159 In the following, the fracture performance of carbon nanotube nanocomposites and the influences of the type, loading, and
surface treatment of CNTs are described in more details.
It is believed that CNTs can effectively increase the toughness of epoxy resins owing
to their highly flexible elastic performance as revealed by Raman spectroscopy of CNT/
epoxy composites containing 5 wt.% SWCNTs under both tensile and compressive loading indicating individual nanotubes sliding within the bundles.160 There is also clear evidence of crack bridging in their SEM micrographs.160 Li et al.26 found similar results in
their nano-indentation and nano-scratching experiments.
Figure 10 shows the variations of the normalized toughness with CNT loading and
surface treatment. The effects of CNTs on the fracture behavior of an epoxy in a systematic
fashion of CNT type (e.g., SWCNT, DWCNT, and MWCNT), CNT loading (up to 0.5 wt.%) and surface functionality (silane and amine group)146,148,159,161 are clearly displayed in this figure. First, CNTs are found to improve KIC of epoxies from »0.7 to »1.4 MPa.m0.5 at low loading up to 0.5 wt.%; but there is one set of untreated CNT data161 (open triangles D) showing a de-toughening effect due to agglomeration of CNTs and poor CNT/epoxy interface interaction. Second, the difference between the toughening efficiency of type of untreated SWCNT, DWCNT, and MWCNT are negligible at 0.1 wt.%. At
0.3 wt.% CNTs, the increase in KIC of epoxy due to untreated DWCNTs compared to untreated SWCNTs and MWCNTs is slightly higher but no more than 10%. Third, surface
treatment of CNTs by silane or amine group produces better dispersion of CNTs in epoxy and enhanced CNT/epoxy interface strength,148,161 leading to further increase in KIC of epoxies but this effect is only marginal (»10%). For example, at 0.3 wt.%, amine-treated DWCNT has a slightly higher KIC value (»8%) compared to its untreated counterpart. It is also noted that amine-treated DWCNT yields a higher toughening efficiency relative to treated and untreated SWCNT and MWCNT. Further, at all CNT loading, silane-treated CNTs give much higher KIC values than untreated CNTs ( 9%).161
Figure 10. Variation of fracture toughness versus carbon nanotube (CNT) content in epoxy resin. KIC values are obtained from Gojny et al. 138 and Ma et al.161 with permission. Note that un-treated and silane-treated CNTs are MWCNTs.161 Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

Finally, it is interesting to point out that a positive effect on the toughness of these
epoxy-based nanocomposites can be achieved by combining well-dispersed and agglomerated CNTs.146 This result agrees with Dasari et al.19 who have shown both exfoliated and intercalated clays are most effective in toughening polyamide 6.
3.1.1 Toughening Mechanism. Crack-bridging by CNTs in epoxy was first suggested as
the main toughening mechanism through circumstantial evidence using SEM (where a
surface crack is induced by chemical etching rather than mechanical loading) and TEM (whereby the crack is opened by electron beam).146 Later, using in situ TEM, Qian and Dickey162 have provided direct evidence of crack bridging of multi-walled carbon nano-
tubes at the crack-wake of a polystyrene (PS) nano-composite film followed by a sword and sheath fracture of the nanotubes. However, since the bridging zone length and the
crack-tip opening displacement are small, the fracture toughness improvement is also
small.

sections.heading: 3.2 Binary Nanocomposites with Halloysites
sections.text:
Halloysites as silicate-based nanotubes are another type of 2D nanofillers studied as a potential toughening agent for epoxy-based materials.163-166 The effect of halloysite content and morphology on the fracture behavior of a toughenable low Tg epoxy (DGEBAPIP) has been studied and illustrated in Fig. 11. The dispersion of halloysite nanotubes in
epoxy is controlled by changing the mixing method (e.g., mechanical mixing and ball milling) and mixing time163 as well as chemical surface treatment163,165 of the silicate
nanotubes. Clearly, the incorporation of halloysites into epoxy increases KIC by 24-78% and GIC by 34–176% compared to neat epoxy. The higher level of intercalation and unfolding of halloysite tubes to platelets yields higher toughening efficiency. Optimal
toughening is obtained in epoxies having 10 wt.% unfolded intercalated halloysite platelets (see symbol^) giving KIC D 1.64 MPa.m0.5 (and KIC,m D 0.92 MPa.m0.5).165 The improvement in the crack resistance of unfolded intercalated halloysite platelet/
epoxy is attributed to microcracking. However, crack bridging, crack deflection, and
pull-out of halloysite tubes are active toughening mechanisms for non-intercalated halloysite nanotube/ epoxy composites.165
3.3 Ternary Nanocomposites with CNT/Rubber Hybrids. There has not been much
work conducted on the fracture behavior of rubber/CNT/epoxy hybrids. A recent study examined the strain rate (0.001–3000 s¡1) sensitivity of the compressive yield behavior of a 5 wt.% nano-rubber/0.25 wt.% CNT/epoxy hybrid.128 According to the test results
obtained, addition of only 0.25 wt.% CNTs into epoxy increases the yield strength of
epoxy; but adding 5 wt.% block copolymer nano-rubber into epoxy decreases the yield
strength. At low strain rates, the hybrid nano-composite gives values similar yield
strength to nano-rubber modified epoxy; at high strain rates, the hybrid nanocomposite behaves similar to neat epoxy.128
The toughening influence of simultaneous additions of carbon nanotubes and rubber particles into epoxy is shown in Fig. 12.167 Here, positive toughening by simultaneously
adding 10.8 wt.% core-shell rubber (CSR) particles (50 nm) and 1 wt.% CNTs (10–20 nm diameter and 50 mm length) into an epoxy matrix is found when compared to epoxies
containing either 10.8 wt.% CSR or 1 wt.% CNT. However, GIC/GIC,m of nano-rubber/ CNT/epoxy hybrid composite (2.55) is larger than the sum of the GIC/GIC,m values of nano-rubber/epoxy (1.60) and CNT/epoxy (1.10) minus that of neat epoxy (1.00) which

sections.heading: 4.1 Binary Nanocomposites with Clay
sections.text:
Clay is one of the most commonly studied nanofillers for improving the performance of
polymers. In its natural state, clay has an aggregated structure of a few microns having a large number of layers held together by cations. Each layer is »1 nm thick and 100- 200 nm in length and width.168 It is difficult to achieve uniform dispersion of clay
nano-platelets in a polymer matrix. In general, three morphologies can be obtained:
micro-dispersion (micro/conventional composite), intercalation and/or exfoliation (both
Figure 11. Variations of (a) normalized fracture toughness and (b) normalized fracture energy of halloysite/epoxy binary nanocomposites versus halloysite content. KIC, GIC, and E values are obtained from Deng et al.163 and Tang et al.165 with permission. In some cases, GIC values are calculated using GIC D K2IC/E. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers. PA and PPA stand for potassium acetate and phenylphosphonic acid, respectively. CTAC stand for cetyl trimethyl ammonium chloride.
Toughening of Epoxy Nanocomposites 87

exfoliated morphology remains a challenge.
Increases in tensile, compressive, and flexural modulus in montmorillonite (MMT) clay/ epoxy nanocomposites have been reported,17,121,169-173 but in some studies reductions in tensile strength and break strain are also observed.169,174,175 The stiffening effect is larger for nano- than micron-size clay.176 It is noted that both strengthening and stiffening effects depend on the dispersion of clay platelets within the polymer matrix.17
Table 3 summarizes previous studies on the mechanical properties of clay/epoxy nanocomposites. The results clearly show that incorporation of nanoclay into epoxy improves the Young’s modulus, tensile strength and fracture toughness/energy.169-172,175,177-184 A linear increase in Young’s modulus with nanoclay loading in epoxy has been reported177,181 and the improvements are theoretically predicted.17,32,177,185 For fracture toughness, it is shown that this property could be increased up to two times compared to neat epoxy.121,175,177,181,183 However, this increase is not as effective as when micron-size or nano-size rubber particles are added, which may be up to 3.5 times17,51,55,57,85,87,109,114,119,121,186,187 or even 5 times.115 It is found that there is an optimal clay loading to maximize the fracture toughness/energy of nanoclay/epoxy composites, since at higher loadings aggregation of clay platelets occurs.17,177,181 (See fracture energy data for highly exfoliated and exfoliated clay in Fig. 14).
There has been great interest on whether an exfoliated or an intercalated morphology is better for KIC and GIC. Figure 14 shows that highly exfoliated 181 and exfoliated179 clay/epoxy nano-composites have highest fracture energies, followed by intercalated
clay/epoxy nanocomposites; and particulate clay/epoxies have the lowest fracture ener-
gies. Hence, at the same clay loading, the exfoliated and intercalated morphologies are
better than the particulate morphology, which is manifest of the “nano” effect on fracture energy. However, several studies have reported higher fracture toughness/energy for intercalated clay/epoxies.172,177,180 Yet others177 have shown that particulate clay can
give higher GIC than exfoliated or intercalated clay in epoxy. This has been explained in terms of the lower effective aspect ratios for the ordered exfoliated and intercalated clays
compared to the particulate clay.
The apparent inconsistencies noted in the literature data sets are likely caused by the
complex structure of clay which yields various dispersion and layered silicates (e.g.,

4.1.1 Toughening Mechanisms. Several toughening mechanisms have been proposed for clay/epoxy nanocomposites which include crack deflection,171 void-induced plastic matrix deformation,177,188 and micro-cracking/crack deflection.121,181 It has been sug-
gested that the operative toughening mechanisms in these clay/epoxies are likely to happen at the micro-scale and that the increase in effective particle volume fraction will also contribute to the increased fracture toughness.168
Zerda and Lesser171 proposed that the fracture surface roughness created when the
crack deflects along the intercalated clay particles is the dominant toughening mechanism
in a highly cross-linked, moderately high Tg epoxy. If this were true, the surface roughness, hence KIC, would increase with increasing clay loading. However, Kinloch and Taylor177 clearly showed an optimum KIC with 3 wt.% clay in a low Tg, lightly cross-linked

epoxy so that crack deflection cannot be responsible whether the clay is aggregated, inter-
calated or orderly exfoliated.
Zilg et al.,172 Ratna et al.,188 and Kinloch and Taylor177 claimed that intercalated
nanoclay layers produce nano-voids and initiate plastic deformation in the epoxy matrix.
But none has provided direct evidence of matrix plasticity to support this toughening pro-
cess. Nonetheless, some researchers have observed shear bands in an intercalated clay/ epoxy at the notch tip, since a low Tg, ductile DGEBA-based epoxy was used. 18 It is believed that the formation of a lower cross-link density or even linear epoxy chains between clay platelets facilitates the initiation of shear bands.18
By contrast, Wang et al.181 did not believe matrix plastic deformation and crack pin-
ning are the responsible toughening mechanisms in these clay/epoxy nanocomposites. By
using both SEM and TEM microscopy, they found that microcracking between adjacent
platelets and crack deflections are major mechanisms in their highly exfoliated (but still
containing few interlayers in randomly distributed thin tactoids) nanoclay/epoxy compo-
sites (i.e., a high Tg epoxy DGEBA and a diethyl toluene diamine (DETDA) hardener); and only small toughness contributions are caused by surface step formation and breakage of clay aggregates in the intercalated clay/epoxy composites. This finding is consistent with microscopy evidence of Marouf et al.121 who also observed microcracking as the
main toughening mechanism in intercalated clay/epoxies.
Overall, the incorporation of nanoclay into epoxy resins modestly improves the
fracture toughness between 15–125% and a “nano” effect exists in highly exfoliated
clay/epoxy nano-composites. There is no agreement on the precise toughening mech-
anisms in these clay/epoxy nanocomposites. It is more likely the dominance of either
microcracking or plastic deformation is the source of energy dissipation in these materials. That matrix plastic deformation can be a major toughening mechanism
which largely stems from the lightly cross-linked matrix. Highly cross-linked epoxies
cannot easily impart shear yielding and complex structure of clay yields different
dispersed and layered silicates. Furthermore, issues such as the roles of interface
properties (e.g., modulus, ductility, thickness) and clay morphology on fracture
toughness, stiffness, and strength properties of clay/epoxy nanocomposites should be
critically studied for their performance optimization.

sections.heading: 4.2 Binary Nanocomposites with Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene is a 1D nanofiller which has been increasingly studied to improve the crack
resistance of epoxies. This is a fast developing area. Overviews on types of graphene,
methods of preparation, characterization techniques, functionalization, chemical, physi-
cal, and mechanical properties, mechanics and potential applications are given by Young et al.43 and Kuila et al.189 The fracture behaviors of graphene/epoxy nanocomposites have also been recently studied by several research groups.190–197 Figure 15 plots the
toughness behavior of graphene nano-platelets in epoxy matrices in normalized K- and
G-graphs. Clearly, incorporation of graphene nanoplatelets increases KIC and GIC of neat epoxy up to 90% and 210%, respectively, confirming graphene is an effective toughener
for epoxies. It is noted that even only very small amount of graphene nano-platelets
(0.1–0.125 wt.%) increases KIC and GIC of the neat epoxies by 70–90% and 115–210%, respectively, with an asymmetric Gaussian distribution. It has also been suggested that crack deflection is a major toughening mechanism190 but quantitative comparisons with analytical model are lacking to date.
Figure 15. Variation of normalized fracture toughness and fracture energy of graphene/epoxy nanocomposite with graphene content. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

Particle size, particle dispersion, and interface strength are important factors on frac-
ture toughening. A previous study on particle size effect and fracture behavior of gra-
phene/epoxy composites has shown that fracture toughness increases with decreasing particle size of graphene nanoplatelets.192 In other studies, the effects of particle dispersion and interface strength on toughening were investigated.193,196,198 As expected, the
obtained results confirmed better dispersion of graphene in epoxy matrix gives higher
fracture toughness and fracture energy.

sections.heading: 4.3 Ternary Nanocomposites with Clay/Rubber Hybrids
sections.text:
From the results discussed in Section 4.1, the incorporation of nanoclay into epoxy resins does not significantly improve the fracture toughness (KIC) and fracture energy (GIC). 121,171-173,175,177,179-181,185 However, rubber modifiers, whether nano-sized or micron-sized, can function as effective toughening agents to overcome brittleness in epoxy polymers.51,53,85,109,114,198,199 Hence, there have been recent efforts to incorporate
simultaneously rubber and clay particles into epoxy matrices to further increase their KIC and GIC values. 121,200-208
Table 4 summarizes the results of previous studies on toughening of nanoclay/rub-
ber/ epoxy ternary composites. KIC is increased in both intercalated and exfoliated nanoclay/rubber/ epoxy ternary nanocomposites compared to nanoclay/epoxies and neat epoxies. However, an exception exists in that Fr€ohlich et al.202 observed a high KIC for neat epoxy ( 1.34 MPa.m0.5) which is larger than the ternary composites ( 1.13-1.19 MPa.m0.5). They claimed extensive matrix shear yielding in neat epoxy, but dominant crack bifurcation/branching in the ternary nanocomposites.202 Compared to rubber/
epoxies, Table 4, the KIC results of ternary clay/rubber/ epoxy composites can be larger, equal, or smaller. Strictly speaking, such comparisons must be viewed cautiously since
the hybrid filler loadings in the ternary composites are higher than the monolithic fillers in the binary composites. More meaningful comparisons of whether a positive or negative
hybrid effect on toughness are given below.
Figure 16 shows two sets of normalized fracture toughness (KIC/KIC,m) and fracture energy (GIC/GIC,m) test data for micro-CTBN/nano-clay 205 and nano-CSR/nano-clay121 hybrids in epoxy. In the micro/nano system (4, ~), CTBN is fixed at 20 wt.% and exfoliated clay varies from 1.5 to 6 wt.%. In the nano/nano system ( , ), CSR is fixed at 15 wt.% and intercalated clay varies from 1.5 to 5 wt.%.
First, consider the micro/nano CTBN/clay/epoxy composites. If no hybrid toughening effect exists, the GIC/GIC,m curve should be shifted upwards by equal amount from the clay/epoxy curve. Clearly, a “negative” hybrid effect at 1.5 and 3 wt.% clay and a
“positive” hybrid effect at 4.5 and 6 wt.% occur. These results are due to the relative
amount of failure features caused by CTBN (cavitation, rubber cohesive fracture, matrix shear deformation) and clay particles (crack bifurcation).205 At low clay loading, e.g.,
3 wt.%, and 20 wt.% CTBN, the failure mechanism is dominated by rubber particles with
small contributions from nanoclay giving a negative effect. At high clay loading, e.g.,
6 wt.%, intense crack bifurcations initiated by the clay particles are found to create multiple fractures with high energy absorption and hence a positive hybrid effect. CTBN particles do not seem to contribute any toughness to this ternary nanocomposite205 which is
unusual. (In terms of KIC/KIC,m the hybrid effect is, however, “negative” as shown in Fig. 16a).
Second, for the nano/nano CSR/clay/epoxy composites, the normalized KIC/KIC,m curve (Fig. 16a) decreases but that for the intercalated clay/epoxy increases with clay

As these two curves converge with increasing clay loading, this means a “negative” hybrid effect on toughness exists.121 (It is expected that the GIC/GIC,m curves will have the same trend and converge). “Negative” hybrid toughening has also been found on nano-rubber/nano-clay/ epoxies by other researchers.206,208
In the nano/nano ternary composites, microscopic examinations have revealed cavi-
tation of rubber particles, matrix shear yielding and microcracking. Competition of these toughening mechanisms121 due to the interaction of rubber and clay particles, location of clay particles, and matrix ductility will decide the form of hybrid toughening effect. For example, Gam et al.204 showed that in an exfoliated clay/nano-rubber/brittle epoxy ter-
nary composite, rubber particle cavitation, limited matrix shear yielding, crack bifurca-
tion, crack deflection, and bridging are active toughening mechanisms. By changing the
brittle epoxy to a ductile epoxy containing similar exfoliated clay, rubber cavitation, mas-
sive matrix shear yielding, and clay delamination become the dominant toughening mechanisms. Referring to Table 4, consider the toughness KIC results of Gam et al. 204 There is

sections.heading: 5.1 Comparison of Toughening Efficiency by 3D, 2D, and 1D Nanofillers
sections.text:
Figure 17 compares the toughening efficiency of 2D CNTs159,161 with 1D graphene190 in
epoxies in normalized KIC/KIC,m. Clearly, 1D graphene is much more effective than 2D CNTs in toughening epoxy for filler loading less than 0.15 wt.%. At 0.125 wt.% graphene platelets, the fracture toughness KIC is increased by 70%. The toughening efficiency of normalized fracture energy (GIC/GIC,m) of 2D halloysite is also compared with 1D clay in epoxies in Fig. 18. Results obtained show that 1D nanoclay, particularly exfoliated and
highly exfoliated clays, is more effective to increase GIC of epoxies than 2D halloysites. However, 1D intercalated clay performs similarly to 2D halloysite.
Figure 19a shows a combined plot of the toughening efficiencies of 3D, 2D,
and 1D nanofillers in epoxies in normalized fracture energy, GIC/GIC,m. The filler loading varies up to 20 wt.%. Since most data are located below 3–5 wt.% loading, they are expanded in Fig. 19b for clarity. In the discussion below, it is assumed
GIC,m is similar for all neat epoxies, but in reality there are some differences. Nonetheless, the significance of this figure is that it can help us select the best
material formulation to satisfy the desired toughness properties for a given

application. Hence, if higher nanofiller loading (> 5 wt.%) can be used, high GIC can be achieved in epoxies toughened with either spherical/wormlike rubber or sil-
ica nanoparticles (3D). But in the range of 1-5 wt.%, exfoliated clay nanoplatelets
(1D) is preferred. When low nanofiller loading (< 0.5 wt.%) is needed, graphene
(1D) is best if only a moderate toughening efficiency provides the required product
properties. In a way, these selections are based on the easiness or difficulty to incorporate the nano-fillers in the epoxy matrices. To summarize, the GIC results suggest the order of toughening efficiency as: 1D nanofillers > 2D nanofillers; and
2D nanofillers > 3D nanofillers for < 5 wt.% loading in epoxy. These relative rat-
ings seem to contradict Fig. 2 showing that the interfacial area cannot be extended
to fracture properties. However, consistent with Fig. 2, for > 5 wt.% loading, 3D
nanofillers like silica are superior to 1D and 2D nanofillers like graphene, clay,
and halloysite as it is hard to mix so much of them into epoxy without cluster and
agglomeration issues. Especially, soft rubber nanoparticles are more effective in toughening epoxies compared to rigid silica nanoparticles. We have also shown in
Section 2.2 on nano-sized rubbers formed by block copolymers in epoxies, 2D
wormlike micelles give higher toughness (KIC) and fracture energy (GIC) than 3D spherical domains (see Table 2 and Fig. 19).

sections.heading: 5.2 Engineering Applications of Epoxy Nanocomposites towards Multi-Functionality
sections.text:
In previous sections, we have shown that incorporating small amounts of 3D, 2D, and 1D
nano-fillers into epoxies has generally increased the fracture toughness (KIC) and/or fracture energy (GIC) above those of neat epoxy (in addition to their stiffening and strengthening effects). These mechanical properties combined with their lightweight make them
suitable for many structural applications where toughness, stiffness, and strength are
required. However, modern trends of applications are often multi-functional and expect
both excellent physical/chemical properties and mechanical/structural integrity. These
functional properties include high electrical and thermal conductivities, high electrical
Figure 18. Comparison of toughening efficiency of 2D halloysite and 1D clay nanofillers in terms of improvement in fracture energy of epoxies. Data are obtained from Refs.163,179,181 with permission. Numbers in brackets refer to reference numbers.

insulation, superior barrier resistance, high optical transparency, outstanding fire retard-
ancy, etc., depending on the requirements of the specific application. It is impossible to
give an exposition of all potential and current applications. So, we only give some typical
and prospective examples below. (a) to (c) are concerned with structural applications and
(d) to (h) are intended for multi-functional applications taking advantages of the electrical, dielectric, thermal, barrier, flame retardancy properties, etc., of the nano-fillers when
incorporated into epoxies.
(a) Epoxies filled with nanofillers, such as silica, CNT, halloysite, clay, or graphene,
can be used as an improved matrix with higher strength and superior fracture toughness for carbon fiber or glass fiber composites,209 thereby increasing the
interlaminar shear strength and toughness. This approach has found potential

markets in aircraft structures, deep-water drilling composite risers, windmill
blades, hydrogen and helium storage tanks, etc., by using epoxy resin master
batches containing different types of nanofillers, e.g., 3D silica nanoparticles (Nanoresins Nanopox F400) and 3D rubber nanoparticles (Kaneka Corporation, Japan), 2D CNTs (Arkema Graphistrength , Nanocyl EpocylTM, and Hype-
rion Fibril ) and 1D nanoclay (Nanocor Nanomer nanoclay). In these fiber
composite structures, CNTs and graphenes can be further employed to detect
damages, and exfoliated clay to prevent gas and pressure leakage.
(b) Instead of modifying the epoxy matrix, but with the same objectives as given in
(a) above, there have been recent developments of hierarchical fibers by synthesizing CNTs directly onto carbon fibers210 which yield similar effect on delamination toughness. Another way to improve delamination resistance is to insert
tough CNT/epoxy or graphene/epoxy interlayers between carbon fiber or glass
fiber prepregs prior to curing. Crack growth in such composite laminates can be
monitored by sensing the electrical voltage or current change due to the progres-
sive fracture of the CNTs or graphene.
(c) Epoxies filled with alumina, silica, and CNT particles can be used individually or
conjointly as structural adhesives in aircrafts and automobiles (e.g., Formula One cars).211 Barrier coatings fabricated with high aspect ratio exfoliated clay212 and CNTs in epoxy can be used effectively against corrosion due to moisture/
gas diffusion such as in underground sewer pipes or steel infrastructures.
(d) Biocompatible epoxy-based nanocomposites are promising for biomedical appli-
cations such as dental restorations,213 tissue regeneration,214 and implantable devices,214 surgical tapes,214 bio-active adhesives,214 among others.
(e) Encapsulating materials for LED devices which require high optical transparency
and good mechanical properties can be synthesized using epoxy resin and core/
shell silica/titania nano-particles by tailoring the refractive index of the particles identical to the epoxy resin.215 It can be envisaged that epoxies containing CNTs
or graphene are suitable for use as windows in aircraft cockpits owing to their
high optical transparency (for views) and high electrical conductivity (for demist
and wear resistance).
(f) Chip encapsulation, underfill, and thermal interface materials required in micro-
electronics assembly can be served by proper selection of nanofillers to add into
epoxy. Chip encapsulation should be resistant to moisture diffusion and ther-
mally stable; this is often achieved by filling epoxy with silica or clay nanoparticles.216 For underfill materials, high thermal conductivity, superior electrical
insulation and low viscosity for good processability are required. These properties can be obtained by using silica coated CNTs217 or silica coated silver nanowires218 embedded in epoxy resin. Finally, thermal interface materials require
high thermal conductivity; this can be achieved by incorporating graphene or
CNTs into epoxy.
(g) Nanofillers such as clay, silica, layer double hydroxides (LDHs), CNTs, and
graphite oxide (GO) are good non-toxic flame retardants which have replaced the more traditional but toxic halogen- and phosphorus-based flame retardants
for polymers and epoxies. However, the char quality derived from CNTs and
GO are much worse than clay and LDHs. Recent developments in this field have been reviewed by Dasari et al.219
(h) Epoxy nanocomposites containing layered clay, spherical silica and titania nano-
particles are found to be excellent dielectrics and insulators.220,221 Their high

has high electrical conductivity and high aspect ratio, are effective electromagnetic interference (EMI) materials with good shielding efficiency.
By extending beyond epoxy matrices to include other polymer (thermosets and
thermo-plastics) matrices, the range of applications of these nanocomposites is substan-
tially broadened and includes biomedical, sensors, optoelectronics, and energy storage
devices. Multi-functional properties are the main trends of current and future R and D
efforts. Interested readers will find further advances and developments in recent monographs by Mai and Yu,222 Tjong and Mai,223 Dasari,224 Friedrich and Brewer,225 and Chrzanowski et al.226

sections.heading: 6. Summary and Future Work
sections.text:
The toughening effects of silica and rubber nanoparticles, carbon nanotubes, halloysites,
clays, and graphene nanoplatelets on epoxy resins have been reviewed. In particular, the
fracture behaviors and toughening mechanisms in epoxy-based binary and ternary nano-
composites are examined. We summarize below the major findings (a) to (d) and point to where future research and development lies.
(a) Incorporation of different kinds of nano-fillers including 3D silica and rubber par-
ticles, 2D CNTs and halloysites, and 1D clay and graphene nano-platelets
improves KIC and GIC of epoxies. Especially, silica and rubber nanoparticles show definite evidence of a “nano” toughening effect when compared to micron-
sized particles of the same loading. (It is, however, noted that for rubber, this
effect occurs at above 10 wt.% loading).
(b) Matrix shear yielding and plastic void growth are responsible for the energy dissi-
pations in silica/epoxy nanocomposites; crack bridging is the main toughening
mechanism identified in CNT/epoxy. In clay/epoxies, further studies are required
to clarify the predominant toughening mechanisms with respect to the different
clay morphology although matrix shear yielding and microcracking are
important.
(c) Cavitation of micron-sized and nano-sized rubber particles occurs in ternary
nanocomposites. While matrix shear yielding and matrix dilation are dominant toughening mechanisms in nano-silica/rubber/epoxy composites, competitions
between matrix shear yielding and microcracking (or crack bifurcation) happen
in nano-clay/rubber/epoxy composites.
(d) Positive hybrid and additive toughening effects on GIC are found in nano-silica/
micron-rubber/epoxy and nano-silica/nano-rubber/epoxy ternary composites,
respectively. Also, positive hybrid effects on GIC occur in nano-clay/micro-rubber/epoxies (at nanoclay loadings of 4.5 and 6 wt.%) and CNT/nano-rubber/
epoxies. But in the nano-clay/nano-rubber/epoxies, negative hybrid toughening has been observed.
Although the “nano” toughening effect on KIC and GIC of binary epoxy-based composites is verified, the “hydrid” effect is more controversial for ternary epoxy-based nano-
composites. Whether positive, negative, or additive, toughening effect exists depends on
the interactions of the two kinds of particles and how different toughening mechanisms
100 B. T. Marouf et al.

are promoted or suppressed, since they cannot be predicted a priori. Analytical and com-
puter simulation studies are required to understand these issues in ternary nanocompo-
sites. Especially, the effects of nanofiller shape and aspect ratio, morphology, interfacial area, and interface strength are important and should be evaluated in cooperation with the
specific toughening mechanisms observed.
Finally, based on our past studies on polymer nanocomposites, including both ther-
moset and thermoplastic matrices, and the current review, we may conclude:
(a) All nanofillers will stiffen and strengthen (except rubber) epoxies according to the
theories of composite mechanics (see Fu et al.81) provided uniform dispersion,
(exfoliation where relevant), surface treatment and/or functionalization can be achieved to avoid any processing difficulties. However, this is quite often costly.
In addition, while all nanofillers will toughen epoxies, this is not true with ther-
moplastic matrices and de-toughening happens. Likewise, the benefits of using
nanofiller modified epoxies as matrices or interleafs for carbon fiber and glass
fiber composites to increase the interlaminar delamination toughness are not
fully realized and less efficient than some conventional methods such as stitching and z-pinning.210,227
(b) We may now have reached the limiting toughness afforded by the incorporation
of nanofillers in resin matrices through such toughening mechanisms as matrix
plastic shear banding, particle debonding/cavitation, plastic void growth, crack
deflection, pinning, and bridging depending on the type and shape of nanofillers
used. So, unless innovative nanofillers are introduced, bringing along new tough-
ening mechanisms, higher improvement in toughness cannot be expected. Even our recent work with 3D interconnected graphene foam (<0.5 wt.%) in epoxy228
cannot improve the toughness by more than 70% - no better than the 1D gra-
phene (see Fig. 16a). Here, crack tip blunting and deflection owing to the porous graphene network and mixed mode crack growth are the principal toughening
mechanisms.
(c) Notwithstanding points (a) and (b) above, polymer nanocomposites are increas-
ingly used in many different industries more for their unique functional proper-
ties rather than their moderately increased fracture toughness and mechanical
properties. Future research should therefore focus on these functional and multi-
functional applications.

Likewise, the benefits of using nanofiller modified epoxies as matrices or interleafs for carbon fiber and glass fiber composites to increase the interlaminar delamination toughness are not fully realized and less efficient than some conventional methods such as stitching and z-pinning.(210,227) (b) We may now have reached the limiting toughness afforded by the incorporation of nanofillers in resin matrices through such toughening mechanisms as matrix plastic shear banding, particle debonding/cavitation, plastic void growth, crack deflection, pinning, and bridging depending on the type and shape of nanofillers used.
